title:
About the first eigenvector of the simple random walk killed upon
  exiting a large bounded domain
abstract:
In this article, we study a discrete version of a Dirichlet problem in an
open bounded set $D\subset \mathbb{R}^d$, in dimension $d\geq 2$. More
precisely, we consider the simple random walk on $\mathbb{Z}^d$, $d\geq 2$,
killed upon exiting the large (bounded) domain $D_N :=(ND)\cap \mathbb{Z}^d$.
We denote by $P_N$ the corresponding transition matrix and we study the
properties of its ($L^2$-normalized) principal eigenvector $\phi_N$ -- one of
our motivation is that the random walk ``conditioned to stay in $D_N$'' is a
random walk among conductances $c_N(x,y) = \phi_N(x)\phi_N(y)$. With
probabilistic arguments and under mild assumptions on the domain, we show that
$\phi_N$ varies regularly, with a uniform control inside $D_N$. We derive
several corollaries, among which a uniform convergence of $\phi_N$ to the first
eigenfunction of the corresponding continuous Dirichlet problem. Our results
may not be new, but our proofs use (simple) probabilistic ideas that could be
helpful in other contexts.
